awd_titl_txt: Large Cardinals, Small Sets and Absoluteness
awd_abstract_narration:
Techniques from mathematical logic can be used to measure the complexity of mathematical concepts. Areas of mathematics with physical applications tend to appear in the low levels of the corresponding complexity hierarchy. Passing to higher levels of complexity enables mathematicians to make connections between different areas of mathematics, and to develop productive general theories. There is a corresponding division of the universe of mathematics into an absolute part, where natural questions tend to be resolved by the standard axioms, and a more abstract part where extensions of the standard axiom system are needed to resolve many fundamental questions. The main focus of Larson's research is the relationship between these parts. The technical machinery involved in this project includes Cohen's forcing technique, axioms asserting the existence of winning strategies in infinite games, and axioms asserting the existence of infinite objects whose existence cannot be proved from the standard axioms for mathematics. These techniques originate in set theory, which serves as the most commonly accepted foundations for mathematics. Larson's work applies them to other areas, including model theory, topology and analysis. Larson hopes to make progress with this approach on several longstanding well-known open problems.

One aspect of Larson's work concerns forcing over models of determinacy to produce canonical models. Woodin's Pmax forcing, when applied to a model of determinacy, produces a model which is maximal for subsets of the set of countable ordinals. One project, initiated by Woodin, and continued by Larson in collaboration with other researchers, is the extent to which this maximality can be made to hold for larger cardinals. Another product, largely in collaboration with Jindrich Zapletal, converts a number of classical ZFC constructions into partial orders, which when applied to determinacy models produce models of fragments of the Axiom of Choice. This approach has resolved a number of classical questions about the relationship between forms of the Axiom of Choice, but may also be able to shine light on newer problems in the theory of Borel equivalence relations. Other aspects of the project include a new approach to Vaught's Conjecture, one of the oldest problems in model theory, and the study of the notion of universally measurability, a fundamental concept from analysis which is still not well understood. Finally, Larson is working on a book on unpublished work of W.H. Woodin, on extensions of the Axiom of Determinacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The PI completed a book with Jindrich Zapletal, titled Geometric Set Theory, which appeared in 2019. The book presents a new approach for producing and analyzing models of set theory satisfying weak forms of the Axiom of Choice, often with the goal of understanding the implications among them. The method introduced in the book has proved to be very flexible, applying to a wide variety of areas both internal and adjacent to set theory, including combinatorics, measure theory and ergodic theory. Several new research projects are being developed using this approach. 

The PI also completed an expository book on Hugh Woodin's theory AD+, which is a strong form of the Axiom of Determinacy. AD+ is now seen to give the correct framework for the general study of models of determinacy, and forms the natural setting for several areas of active research. The book develops the basic theory, concentrating on results from the 1990's. The PI plans to start work on a follow-up book continuing toward the present day. 

With Grigor Sargsyan, the PI proved a result showing that one of the standard methods used in inner model theory for building minimal canonical models for large cardinals cannot succeed throughout the large cardinal hierarchy. In particular, by forcing with Woodin's Pmax order over models produced by Sargsyan, we produced a model in which Jensen's square principle fails at both omega_3 and omega_4. The requisite models were produced from a Woodin limit of Woodin cardinals. Combined with results of Jensen, Schimmerling, Schindler and Steel, this shows that the core model construction defined by these authors consistently fails to converge. 

With Will Brian, the PI introduced and studied a finite combinatorial principle related to the converge of real series. Optimal upper bounds for this principle were found. 

With Kostas Beros, the PI resolved a long-standing problem in the theory of hypercyclic vectors, showing for instance that the common hypercyclic vectors for a Borel set of weighted shifts can be properly analytic. 

With Saharon Shelah, the PI showed that consistently there is a low projective bound for the complexity of all universally measurable subsets of the real line. The family of universally measurable sets is important in a number of current research areas, but remains poorly understood.  

Also with Zapletal, the PI has identified a large class of partial orders which preserve universally measurable sets, in a way that makes them unsuitable for attacking some of the important outstanding problems in the area. 

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2022
Modified by: Paul B Larson
